docs.lead_paragraph: Beijing needs to speed up economic reform and curb the dominance of state companies or risk an economic slowdown and a possible crisis, the biggest European business group in China said Tuesday.

headline.main: Business Group Says China Needs to Speed Up Reform
headline.print_headline: Business Group Says China Needs to Speed Up Reform

docs.snippet: Beijing needs to speed up economic reform and curb the dominance of state companies or risk an economic slowdown and a possible crisis, the biggest European business group in China said Tuesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: An angry Gov. Terry McAuliffe was forced to retreat after losing a fight with the Republican-dominated General Assembly.

headline.main: After First Plan Is Blocked, Virginia Governor Reduces Medicaid Expansion Goals
headline.print_headline: After First Plan Is Blocked, Virginia Governor Reduces Medicaid Expansion Goals

docs.abstract: Virginia Gov Terry McAuliffe, who in June ordered his cabinet to devise plan to expand Medicaid unilaterally, announces that only 25,000 uninsured Virginians will be receiving coverage, far fewer than 400,000 he has said are eligible if state expands Medicaid under Affordable Care Act; move is sign of how McAuliffe has been forced to retreat after losing fight with Republican-dominated General Assembly.
docs.snippet: An angry Gov. Terry McAuliffe was forced to retreat after losing a fight with the Republican-dominated General Assembly.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Robert A. McDonald, the new secretary of Veterans Affairs, said it would be difficult, but the department needed to hire “tens of thousands” of doctors, nurses and clinicians to reduce wait times.

headline.main: New V.A. Secretary Says Hiring Spree Is Needed to Meet Patient Demand
headline.print_headline: New V.A. Secretary Says Hiring Spree Is Needed to Meet Patient Demand

docs.abstract: Robert A McDonald, new secretary of Veterans Affairs, says hiring spree is needed to meet patient demands at department's hospitals and clinics; pledges also to flatten department's hierarchical structure, eliminate benchmarks that created unintended incentives to manipulate waiting-time data, transform management culture and make it easier for veterans to receive care.
docs.snippet: Robert A. McDonald, the new secretary of Veterans Affairs, said it would be difficult, but the department needed to hire “tens of thousands” of doctors, nurses and clinicians to reduce wait times.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sylvia Mathews Burwell, the secretary of health and human services, said that she would emphasize improving the management and operation of the site.

headline.main: Health Chief Seeks to Focus on Insurance Site
headline.print_headline: Health Chief Seeks to Focus on Insurance Site

docs.abstract: Health and Human Services Sec Sylvia Mathews Burwell announces in first major speech that she intends to move beyond politics of health care and work with members of both parties to improve management and operation of HealthCare.gov, website used by millions of Americans to sign up for insurance coverage.
docs.snippet: Sylvia Mathews Burwell, the secretary of health and human services, said that she would emphasize improving the management and operation of the site.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sandeep Jauhar tells the story of two midlife crises: the author’s own, and that of modern American medicine, now in about its fourth decade under managed care.

headline.seo: In 'Doctored,' Shortcomings of Health Care and Doctor
headline.main: A Doctor’s Malaise, and a Profession’s
headline.print_headline: A Doctor’s Malaise, and a Profession’s

docs.abstract: Florence Williams reviews book Doctored: The Disillusionment of an American Physician by Sandeep Jauhar.
docs.snippet: Sandeep Jauhar tells the story of two midlife crises: the author’s own, and that of modern American medicine, now in about its fourth decade under managed care.

docs.lead_paragraph: The move by the Drug Enforcement Administration is intended to help reduced the stockpile of unused controlled drugs in homes, which until now could be handed over only to the police.

headline.main: D.E.A. to Allow Return of Unused Pills to Pharmacies
headline.print_headline: D.E.A. to Allow Return of Unused Pills to Pharmacies

docs.abstract: Drug Enforcement Administration, in effort to reduce stockpile of of unneeded medicines in homes, announces new regulation that allows consumers to return unused prescription medications that are designated as controlled substances to pharmacies.
docs.snippet: The move by the Drug Enforcement Administration is intended to help reduced the stockpile of unused controlled drugs in homes, which until now could be handed over only to the police.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Mississippi city of Starkville will become the first in the right-leaning state to extend benefits to same-sex partners of its employees, according to local media reports.

headline.main: City to Become First in Mississippi to Grant Same-Sex Spouse Benefits: Report
headline.print_headline: City to Become First in Mississippi to Grant Same-Sex Spouse Benefits: Report

docs.snippet: The Mississippi city of Starkville will become the first in the right-leaning state to extend benefits to same-sex partners of its employees, according to local media reports.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite steady job growth and a drop in the unemployment rate from 10 percent during 2009 to 6.1 percent in August, most Americans have received little increase in pay.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama's top health adviser on Monday called for an end to partisan bickering over Obamacare, saying the public and businesses are sending a clear message to Washington that it is time to move on with implementing the law.

headline.main: Top U.S. Health Adviser Wants End to Partisan Fighting Over Obamacare
headline.print_headline: Top U.S. Health Adviser Wants End to Partisan Fighting Over Obamacare

docs.snippet: President Barack Obama's top health adviser on Monday called for an end to partisan bickering over Obamacare, saying the public and businesses are sending a clear message to Washington that it is time to move on with implementing the law.

docs.lead_paragraph: Many people newly insured by Medicaid under the federal health care law are seeking treatment in hospital emergency rooms, one of the most expensive medical settings, a study released Monday concludes.

headline.main: Study: Rise in ER Visits After Medicaid Expansion
headline.print_headline: Study: Rise in ER Visits After Medicaid Expansion

docs.snippet: Many people newly insured by Medicaid under the federal health care law are seeking treatment in hospital emergency rooms, one of the most expensive medical settings, a study released Monday concludes.
